subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns

messageBody:
On Wed, 2006-02-22 at 19:38 -0600, Robert Wenner wrote:
> On Friday 17 February 2006 18:24, Joe Schmetzer wrote:
> > I've just updated the JUnit Anti-patterns page I maintain at
> > http://www.exubero.com/junit/antipatterns.html. I'd be interested in
> > any feedback, if people want to suggest additions or improvements.
>
> Hm, some of these items seem to be bad ideas. But anti pattern sounds too
> strong for my taste.

Actually, I recently came across the XUnit Test Patterns website at
http://xunitpatterns.com/ . Gerard Meszaros uses the term "Test Smells",
which probably would be more agreeable to you. However, I'm inclined to
leave the anti-patterns page at its current location, as it's getting
fairly well known at that spot (not that I couldn't set up a 203
response).

> Anyhow...
>
> No unit tests: sounds like saying "you sing wrong because you don't sing
> at all". If I don't test, I surley do something wrong, but I am not doing
> unit testing wrong.

You are right, in that it shows a problem with development methodology,
and not the tests themselves. That section is meant to have a slightly
facetious tone, and possibly doesn't belong there (I've nearly removed
it a number of times). In the end, I liked the point that it was making,
but I probably should consider moving it to a less prominent position.

> I don't like the section heading "Refactoring" because a refactoring is
> something different. Your 'refactorings' actively change the code and its
> behavior, while AFAIK a refactoring in terms of THE book doesn't do that.
> Maybe 'fixes' or 'solutions' would be better headings?

You're right, in that "refactoring" refers to improving internal
structure without changing external behaviour. The anti-patterns page
recommends a number of transformations that are in fact refactoring by
this definition (e.g. catching unexpected exceptions), but it also
recommends a number of changes to existing test behaviour.

In the end, I was basing the headings on the original anti-patterns book
by Brown et al, which use the term "Refactored Solution". Since I
skipped over most of the other headings anyway, there probably isn't
much reason to dogmatically stick to that particular heading.

> Missing assertions may be ok, for example in a test that was written for a
> bug report where the code threw but shouldn't do so. This test can just
> have a comment like // This line throws if bug 123 is not fixed.

True. In this case, it's more of a smell, along the lines of if there is
no assertion, maybe the programmer didn't understand what they were
trying to test. In your example, it is clear what is happening, but I
have seen many cases of long meandering tests that didn't contain any
asserts. In the end, the test only confirmed that the code didn't throw
exceptions, without making any stronger statements about what the
expected behaviour should have been.

I think your example hightlights the importance of context in
determining if a particular style of programming is problematic or
normal.

> I also don't have problems with multiple assertions, if it's only two or
> three. For example I may assert some object to be not null before
> asserting its properties.

Yeah, I agree here. JBR gave a good example that explained the logic
here more clearly.

> Superficial coverage: this can happen for TDD beginners, and unless there
> is a requirement to check something not on the happy path, I wouldn't
> make this a hard rule. For example, if I write tests that deal with
> people's age (as an integer), I see no problem with not testing negative
> values, if the code is used in a context where this is other classes
> responsibility.
>
> An example for the "only easy tests" section would be helpful.
>
> I agree on the overly complex tests. However, you may not always be able
> to just refactor as you'd like.
>
> You could add time/date and randomness to the external dependencies.
Nice ones.

Thanks for your comments.

Cheers!
